etymologies: late 15th century; earliest use found in Higden's Polychronicon. From classical Latin ōstiārius ostiarius; compare -ary

definitions: A doorkeeper, especially of a church; specifically a member of the lowest of the four lesser orders in the pre-Reformation Western Church, and later in the Roman Catholic Church.

notes.text: The Roman Catholic order of ostiary was suppressed by Pope Paul VI in 1972.
